sen.j: 城主大名（じょうしゅだいみょう）とは、近世江戸時代における大名の格式の一つであり、大名家をその居地・居城で区別する国主（国持大名） - 準国主 - 城主 - 城主格 - 無城（陣屋）の5階級のうち、国許の屋敷に城が認められている大名をいう。
sen.e: Joshu daimyo (daimyo who is allowed to live in a castle) is one of Kyakushiki codes (amendments and enforcement regulations [of the ritsuryo]) in the early-modern times of the Edo period, and refers to a daimyo, who was allowed to have a castle as his residence in his kunimoto (hometown), among Daimyo families (feudal lord families) classified according to their resident provinces and resident castles into five ranks: kokushu (landed daimyos), jun (associate) kokushu, joshu (lord of a castle), joshukaku (joshu class), mujo (without a castle) (jinya [regional government office]).

Joshu daimyo (daimyo who is allowed to live in a castle) is a social status in the early-modern times of the Edo period, and refers to a daimyo, who was allowed to have a castle as his residence in his kunimoto (hometown), among Daimyo families (feudal lord families) classified according to their resident provinces and resident castles into five ranks: kokushu (landed daimyos), jun (associate) kokushu, joshu (lord of a castle), joshukaku (joshu class), mujo (without a castle) (jinya [regional government office]).
sen.cmt: 「大名の格式の1つであり」に対応する英語が意味不明でしたので変更しました。
sen.e: Joshu daimyo (daimyo who is allowed to live in a castle) is a social status in the early-modern times of the Edo period, and refers to a daimyo, who was allowed to have a castle as his residence in his kunimoto (hometown), among Daimyo families (feudal lord families) classified according to their resident provinces and resident castles into five ranks: kokushu (landed daimyos), jun (associate) kokushu, joshu (lord of a castle), joshukaku (joshu class), mujo (without a castle) (jinya [regional government office]).

sen.j: その他、大名統制には、並大名が諸大夫（従五位下）である官位が四品以上に昇進する大名家一覧であったり、伺候席によって区別されていた。
sen.e: In addition, for controlling daimyos there were a list of daimyos containing nami-daimyo (low-class daimyos) appointed to Shodaifu (Jugoinoge [Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade]) and another list of those who could be promoted to Shihon (the fourth-ranked Imperial Prince) or higher; and they were distinguished by the rooms where they were assigned to wait before being received in audience.
sen.cmt: Wikipediaによりますと、「初任四品以上に叙される家」と「初任従五位下に叙された後、昇任する家」の2つの表があったようです。
sen.e: In addition, for controlling daimyos there were a list of daimyos containing nami-daimyo (low-class daimyos) appointed to Shodaifu (Jugoinoge [Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade]) and another list of those who could be promoted to Shihon (the fourth-rank) or higher; and they were distinguished by the rooms where they were assigned to wait before being received in audience.
sen.cmt: Shihon (the fourth-ranked Imperial Prince) を、 Shihon (the fourth-rank) にしました。ここでは恐らく、親王等について言及しているわけではないので。
sen.e: In addition, for controlling daimyos there were a list of daimyos containing nami-daimyo (low-class daimyos) appointed to Shodaifu (Jugoinoge [Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade]) and another list of those who could be promoted to Shihon (the fourth-rank) or higher; and they were distinguished by the rooms where they were assigned to wait before being received in audience.

sen.j: 享保2年（1717年）の『武家諸法度』によると、城主は櫓・塀・門以下は届出をし許可を得たうえで補修することが可能で、石塁・石壁が壊れたときは奉行に報告し、その差図を受けることとなっていた。
sen.e: According to "Buke Shohatto" (code for the warrior households) issued in 1717, a joshu could repair building parts equal to or less than a tower, fence or gate after submitting an application and obtaining an approval; and, when a stone wall was broken, he was supposed to report to bugyo (commissioner [in charge of repair and management]) and to receive his instruction.

According to "Buke Shohatto" (code for the warrior households) issued in 1717, a joshu could repair building parts equal to or less than a tower, fence or gate after submitting an application and obtaining an approval; and, when a stone wall was broken, the joshu was supposed to report to bugyo (commissioner [in charge of repair and management]) and to receive his instruction.
sen.cmt: he を the joshu に変更しました。
sen.e: According to "Buke Shohatto" (code for the warrior households) issued in 1717, a joshu could repair building parts equal to or less than a tower, fence or gate after submitting an application and obtaining an approval; and, when a stone wall was broken, the joshu was supposed to report to bugyo (commissioner [in charge of repair and management]) and to receive his instruction.

sen.j: このことから徳川幕藩体制下における城の定義は石垣の上に塀と櫓を有しているものとされていた。
sen.e: For this reason it was said that the definition of shiro (castle) under the Tokugawa shogunate system was a structure including fences and a tower on a stone wall.
For this reason it was said that the shiro (castle) under the Tokugawa shogunate system was defined as a structure including fences and a tower on a stone wall.
sen.cmt: the definition is a strocture という英文を、 was defined as a structure…に変更しました。
sen.e: For this reason it was said that the shiro (castle) under the Tokugawa shogunate system was defined as a structure including fences and a tower on a stone wall.

sen.j: 佐土原藩 - 佐土原城

tit.e: Joshukaku Daimyo (daimyo without castle, but treated almost as joshu daimyo)
Joshukaku Daimyo (daimyo without castle, but treated almost as joshu daimyo)

sen.j: 城主格大名とは国許の屋敷が陣屋である大名のうち、城主に準ずる待遇城主格大名の優遇例
sen.e: A joshukaku daimyo was a daimyo whose residence in his hometown was a jinya, but who was treated like a joshu daimyo; which is an example of preferential treatment of a daimyo without a castle as joshu daimyo.

A joshukaku daimyo was a daimyo whose residence in his hometown was a jinya, but who was treated like a joshu daimyo; which is an example of preferential treatment of a daimyo without a castle as joshu daimyo.

A joshukaku daimyo was a daimyo whose residence in his hometown was a jinya, but who was treated like a joshu daimyo; which is an example of preferential treatment of a daimyo without a castle as joshu daimyo.

sen.j: 老中の最低家禄が2万5,000石であり、これに満たない場合は老中格となり、無城大名は城主格大名とされた
sen.e: The minimum karoku (hereditary stipend) of roju (member of shogun's council of elders) was 25,000 koku (1 koku = approximately 180.39 liters) rice crop yields, and, if a daimyo whose position was close to roju, but was receiving less, he was treated as rojukaku; likewise a mujo daimyo (a daimyo without a castle) was treated as joshukaku daimyo.

The minimum karoku (hereditary stipend) of roju (member of shogun's council of elders) was 25,000 koku (1 koku = approximately 180.39 liters) rice crop yields, and, if a daimyo whose position was close to roju, but was receiving less, he was treated as rojukaku; likewise a mujo daimyo (a daimyo without a castle) was treated as joshukaku daimyo.

The minimum karoku (hereditary stipend) of roju (member of shogun's council of elders) was 25,000 koku (1 koku = approximately 180.39 liters) rice crop yields, and, if a daimyo whose position was close to roju, but was receiving less, he was treated as rojukaku; likewise a mujo daimyo (a daimyo without a castle) was treated as joshukaku daimyo.

sen.j: 若年寄の序列では、後任でも城主は先任である無城の上席であった。
sen.e: In the hierarchy of wakadoshiyori (assistants to roju in the Edo bakufu), a joshu daimyo, even if nominated later, was placed higher than a mujo nominated earlier.
In the hierarchy of wakadoshiyori (assistants to roju in the Edo bakufu), a joshu daimyo, even if nominated later, was placed higher than a mujo nominated earlier.
In the hierarchy of wakadoshiyori (assistants to roju in the Edo bakufu), a joshu daimyo, even if nominated later, was placed higher than a mujo nominated earlier.

sen.j: 無城大名の嫡子は従五位下諸大夫の叙任がなく、乗物（駕籠）の使用が許されなかった
sen.e: A legitimate child of a mujo daimyo was not nominated to a Shodaibu (low rank official) at Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) and was not allowed to ride a vehicle (kago [palaquin]).
A legitimate child of a mujo daimyo was not nominated to a Shodaibu (low rank official) at Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) and was not allowed to ride a vehicle (kago [palaquin]).
A legitimate child of a mujo daimyo was not nominated to a Shodaibu (low rank official) at Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) and was not allowed to ride a vehicle (kago [palaquin]).

sen.j: 城主格大名は国許の陣屋を城に転換することが許されず、実際には城門の構築を許されるのみであった
sen.e: A joshukaku daimyo was not allowed to convert his jinya to a castle, actually allowed to build only a castle gate.
A joshukaku daimyo was not allowed to convert his jinya to a castle, actually allowed to build only a castle gate.
A joshukaku daimyo was not allowed to convert his jinya to a castle, actually allowed to build only a castle gate.

sen.j: 但し、四品（従四位下）になると、城・無城に関係なく、官職と任官年次で区分されていた。
sen.e: However, those who were Shihon (the fourth rank) Jushiinoge [Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade]) were ranked by government posts and appointment years regardless of possession of a castle.
However, those who were Shihon (the fourth rank) Jushiinoge [Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade]) were ranked by government posts and appointment years regardless of possession of a castle.
However, those who were Shihon (the fourth rank) Jushiinoge [Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade]) were ranked by government posts and appointment years regardless of possession of a castle.

sen.j: 従五位下諸大夫では、江戸城中の序列において、万石以下端数を切捨てた石高で同高の城主大名の次席に位置した（「順席」における例.5万3,000石城主格藤堂家は5万石城主溝口家の次席であった）をうける大名をいった。
sen.e: In the hierarchy within the Edo-jo Castle, a Shodaibu at Jugoinoge was placed next to a joshu daimyo whose Kokudaka ([crop] yield) rounded down to the nearest 10,000 koku was equal to that of a joshu daimyo, (an example of which was Todo family, a Joshukaku with 53,000 koku placed next to Mizoguchi family, a joshu with 50,000 koku).

In the hierarchy within the Edo-jo Castle, a Shodaibu at Jugoinoge was placed next to a joshu daimyo whose Kokudaka ([crop] yield) rounded down to the nearest 10,000 koku was equal to that of a joshu daimyo, (an example of which was Todo family, a Joshukaku with 53,000 koku placed next to Mizoguchi family, a joshu with 50,000 koku).

In the seating hierarchy within Edo-jo Castle, any Shodaibu of Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade whose kokudaka (the assessed value of their landholdings in rice), rounded down to the nearest 10,000 koku, was equal to that of a joshu (castle lord) daimyo, was seated one notch down from such joshu daimyo (for example, the Todo family, a Joshukaku with 53,000 koku, was seated one notch below the Mizoguchi family, a joshu with 50,000 koku).
sen.cmt: チェッカーのコメントに対して対応しました。

sen.j: 元和 (日本)元年（1615年）一国一城令によって主城以外が破却された後、取立てられた家や分知大名が多数出現して与うるべき城地が不足する。
sen.e: After castles other than main castles were abandoned by Ikkoku Ichijo Rei (Law of One Castle per Province) in1615, many daimyos who were newly promoted or who had their domains subdivided appeared, causing the lack of the sites to be given for building castles.

After castles other than main castles were abandoned by Ikkoku Ichijo Rei (Law of One Castle per Province) in1615, many daimyos who were newly promoted or who had their domains subdivided appeared, causing the lack of the sites to be given for building castles.

After castles other than main castles were abandoned by Ikkoku Ichijo Rei (Law of One Castle per Province) in1615, many daimyos who were newly promoted or who had their domains subdivided appeared, causing the lack of the sites to be given for building castles.

sen.j: そこで、長年若年寄を務めた家や、旧家・名族を城主格に処遇し、幕末の慶応3年（1867年）で19家あった。
sen.e: For this reason, families who had served as wakadoshiyori for many years, and old and noble families were treated as joshukaku, and at the end of Edo Period there were 19 such families at the end of Edo Period (1867).

For this reason, families who had served as wakadoshiyori for many years, and old and noble families were treated as joshukaku, and at the end of Edo Period there were 19 such families at the end of Edo Period (1867).

For this reason, families who had served as wakadoshiyori for many years, and old and noble families were treated as joshukaku, and at the end of Edo Period there were 19 such families at the end of Edo Period (1867).

sen.j: 安中藩（城主）→西尾藩（城主）→掛川藩（城主）→与板藩（城主格） 2万石 譜代 帝鑑間
sen.e: Annaka Domain (joshu)=> Nishio Domain (joshu)=> Kakegawa Domain (joshu)=> Yoita Domain (joshukaku); 20,000 kokus, fudai (hereditary daimyos); Teikan no ma (room for fudai daimyo of Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade and Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade)
